isis.stitle: TSI 97-12-26 - Navistar's New Engine Control Module For All International® Electronically Controlled Engines Built October, 1997 and Later (T 444E Engine Serial Number 634234 and Above) (DT 466E and 530E Engine Serial Number 1075289 and Above)

subjectgroup.subject: Navistar's New Engine Control Module For All International® Electronically Controlled Engines Built October, 1997 and Later (T 444E Engine Serial Number 634234 and Above) (DT 466E and 530E Engine Serial Number 1075289 and Above)

lev1.title: General Information
lev1.para: An engine mounted electronic control module (ECM)( Figure 1 and Figure 2), is released for Navistar's full line of Electronically Controlled diesels, the T 444E, DT 466E and 530E International® brand engines. The new "Navistar ECM" consolidates the current three modules used for monitoring and controlling engine and vehicle performance. The previous electronic modules were chassis mounted. Production began October 27, 1997 for the DT 466E and 530E engines with serial number 1075289 and above; and November 3, 1997 for the T 444E engines with serial number 634234 and above.
The three modules replaced by the new ECM are:

figure.caption: Figure 1. T 444E Engine Equipped With Navistar ECM (Engine Control Module)
Figure 2. DT 466E Engine (530E Similar) Equipped With Navistar ECM (Engine Control Module)

lev1.para: Strategies of operation are very similar between the two systems. The functions of the three modules used in the prior system are consolidated into a single controller. By combining the three modules to one it enhances engine and vehicle operating and control features, also electrical harnesses are reduced to only two. One is the engine harness, containing wiring to engine mounted components. The other harness is the chassis harness, containing wiring to chassis mounted components including battery and ignition power supply.

lev1.title: Features
lev1.para: A new Change Oil Lamp (COL)standard feature is added to the dash panel. This feature can be programmed for the amber lamp to illuminate when it is time to change the engine oil. The COL can be programmed in terms of vehicle miles, hours or calculated fuel consumption. These service interval limits may be adjusted or the COL feature may be turned off.

New engine protection systems are optional features and controlled by the ECM. The red Oil and Water Lamp (OWL) and the Engine Alarm Buzzer are intended to be turned on when conditions are present that will cause impending damage to the engine. The level of protection is dependent upon which Engine Warning and Protection System is turned on in the ECM. When ignition switch is in the "On" position power is available at the OWL lamp and alarm. The lamp and the alarm are turned "On" when the ECM provides a path to ground. A momentary bulb check can be visually observed each time the ignition switch is turned on by the operator.

Hydraulic pressure governing (HPG); this is a new optional feature used for closed loop control of hydraulic pressure based on an external hydraulic pressure input and a programmable desired hydraulic pressure. Controls will be wired to the ECM to enable the operation and a sensor is used to signal operational pressure. This feature is mainly for fluid delivery pumps, especially fire truck applications.

lev1.title: Sensors
lev1.para: The following engine and chassis mounted sensors are changed to accommodate the Navistar Engine Control Module.

The manifold absolute pressure (MAP) sensor is changed. The prior sensor that was mounted on the cowl is replaced by an analog sensor mounted directly in the intake air stream; in the top of the valve cover. With this sensor the signal voltage increases as the boost pressure increases. Note, this is the same sensor as the prior sensor used for engine oil pressure.

The engine oil pressure (EOP) sensor is changed. The EOP sensor is now required on all engines equipped with the Navistar ECM, unless the customer prefers their own sensing system. The new sensor will now read up to 100 psi. It is an analog sensor with which the signal voltage increases with an increase in pressure. As previously mentioned in this letter an Engine Warning and Protection feature is available and should be used in conjunction with the EOP sensor. It will warn driver of low engine oil pressure condition and can be programmed to shut the engine down.

Clutch pedal switch (sensor) is replaced by a single pole double throw switch. Operation will be similar, however, the switch will now be wired in series with the engine crank inhibit relay (standard relay) controlled by the ECM.
Cruise on/off switch (sensor) is now a continuous switch and no longer will it be wired in series with a resistor block, but will send a digital signal directly to the controller.

Brake switches (sensors); hydraulic brakes will use a double pole single throw switch with two separate circuits to the controller. Straight truck air brakes will use two air pressure switches, each with a signal to the controller. Tractor air brakes will use a single switch with parallel circuits to the controller. Both of the brake inputs to the controller will be normally open.

lev1.title: Actuators
lev1.para: The ECM will control fan clutch and shutter operation determined by engine temperature. The engine temperature is monitored by an Engine Fan Control which provides the proper logic to determine when the fan should be turned on or off by energizing/de-energizing the fan drive solenoid.

The engine crank inhibit relay is replaced with a standard relay controlled by the ECM. The relay receives signals from the ignition switch and ECM to close the relay. Current to the relay is supplied from the neutral safety switch with automatic transmission or clutch with manual transmission.

Starter relay is now mounted on the center of the cowl next to the power relay. The starter relay is used to switch battery power to the cranking motor solenoid when the crank inhibit relay (standard relay) is energized. With thermal overcrank protection, the relay is also controlled by the overcrank thermocouple.

Battery power to the ECM will pass through a single power relay. The electronic control module requires a 12 volt source of power in order to perform its functions. It receives this operating power directly from the vehicle batteries via the ECM relay-contacts each time the ignition key switch is turned to the "On" position. Turning the ignition switch "On" causes the ECM to provide an internal ground to the coil side of the ECM relay. This causes the relay to close its contacts and provide the ECM with the power necessary to perform its various functions.
